qas.question: Paleoptera and Neoptera are what kind of insect orders?
An insects hard body parts are called what?
Insect's wings fold flat over their what?
Neoptera can be divided into what kind of "based" group?
Paraneopter and Endopterygota are closely what?

context: Paleoptera and Neoptera are the <a0_0>winged<a0_0/> orders of insects differentiated by the presence of hardened body parts called <a1_0>sclerites<a1_0/>, and in the Neoptera, muscles that allow their wings to fold flatly over the <a2_0>abdomen<a2_0/>. Neoptera can further be divided into incomplete metamorphosis-based (Polyneoptera and Paraneoptera) and complete <a3_0>metamorphosis-based<a3_0/> groups. It has proved difficult to clarify the relationships between the orders in Polyneoptera because of constant new findings calling for revision of the taxa. For example, the Paraneoptera have turned out to be more closely <a4_0>related<a4_0/> to the Endopterygota than to the rest of the Exopterygota. The recent molecular finding that the traditional louse orders Mallophaga and Anoplura are derived from within Psocoptera has led to the new taxon Psocodea. Phasmatodea and Embiidina have been suggested to form the Eukinolabia. Mantodea, Blattodea, and Isoptera are thought to form a monophyletic group termed Dictyoptera.
